 INTRODUCTION 
The evidence in this proceeding shows that the proposed Acquisition  of ALLETE 
(“Acquisition ”) by Global Infrastructure Partners and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
(together, the “Partners”) poses significant risks to ratepayers which outweigh any claimed 
benefits: the Acquisition  may not help Minnesota Power’s (the “Company”) compliance with the  
Carbon Free Standard, it does not guarantee access to capital, it is likely to contribute to higher rates,  and it would result in a loss of local control and reduced transparency. Based on  this 
evidence, the Administrative Law Judge (“ALJ”) correctly recognized that the Acquisition  is not 
in the public interest, setting out her factual findings and legal conclusions in a thorough and well-supported report (“ALJ Report”) which recommended denial of the Acquisition .
1  
In the face of this evidence, the Compa ny and the Partners (together, “Petitioners”) 
attempt to discredit the ALJ Report, misstate the legal standard, mischaracterize the factual record, and greatly overstate the effects of the very limited commitments contained in the Proposed Settlement with the Department of Commerce (“DOC”).
2 Many of the commitments in 
the Proposed Settlement are illusory, and it does not offer any benefits sufficient to tip the balance in favor of approval. The Commission should not allow Petitioners’ tactics to distract from the essential facts of this case: while the proposed Acquisition  might be lucrative for the 
Partners or for ALLET E’s current shareholders, the record shows that it is a bad deal for

I. THE ALJ REPORT IS IMPARTIAL,  FAIR, AND THOROUGH.   
The ALJ Report reaches well -supported, carefully reasoned conclusions based on a 
thorough and impartial review of the evidence in this proceeding. Because Petitioners disagree 
with the ALJ’s conclusions, they attempt to discredit the ALJ Report by baselessly suggesting 
that the report is somehow one-sided or unfair, or that the ALJ failed to consider the evidence offered by Petitioners.
3 This i s nonsense.  
The record in this case includes hundreds of pages of testimony put forward by twenty-
two witnesses, including eleven witnesses sponsored by Petitioners. The ALJ held a three -day 
evidentiary hearing  and received two rounds of briefing by the parties. The ALJ Report makes 
clear that the ALJ carefully considered all of the evidence, including evidence put forward by Petitioners, not just the evidence favorable to Intervenors. The ALJ Report includes ex tensive 
discussion of Petitioners’ evidence and Petitioners’ contentions throughout its analysis of each issue.
4 The ALJ did not ignore Petitioners’ evidence—rather, she carefully weighed the 
credibility of the testimony and evidence offered by each party,  and ultimately determined that 
Petitioners’ evidence on several key issues was less credible than that offered by Intervenors.5 
The ALJ elaborated on the basis for these credibility determinations.6 While the Commission

should give significant weight to the ALJ’s factual findings and credibility determinations.8 
Petitioners provide no valid reason to question the ALJ’s credibility determinations. 
Petitioners fail to meaningfully respond to the ALJ’s finding that “the Petitioner’s agreements 
and private discussions do not comport with their public statements ,”9 nor do they rebut the 
ALJ’s conclusion that Petitioners’ misleading representations about last -minute changes to a key 
agreement setting out Petitioner commitments had “absolutely no credibility.”10 
The Petitioners complain that the ALJ Report included language similar to I ntervenors’ 
proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law.11 But there is nothing improper about this: the 
ALJ asked all parties, including Petitioners, to file proposed findings of fact along with reply briefing in May.
12 In light of the ALJ’s determination that I ntervenors’ evidence was more 
credible than Petitioners’ evide nce, it is entirely appropriate that the ALJ Report would 
incorporate language from Intervenors’ proposed findings in the Report. This routine practice 
does nothing to change the fact that the ALJ Report is evenhanded and impartial.  
Moreover, even if the ALJ had adopted Intervenors’ proposed findings in their entirety 
and without modification, which is not the case here, the published Minnesota cases cited by Petitioners confirm that a judge’s  adoption of one party’s proposed findings of fact and

Petitioners fail to show that the ALJ Report is anything other than unbiased and well -supported. 
Notably, DOC (which opposed the Acquisition  as recently as May and sponsored 
witnesses who raised numerous concerns about the transaction14) does not question the fairness

 Ironically, while Petitioners attempt to malign the ALJ Report, it is Petitioners who 
present a one-sided view of the evidence in this case. Petitioners’ proposed findings of fact and 
conclusions of law (provided as Attachment D to Petitioners’ exceptions) distort the record in this case by focusing exclusively on alleged benefits of the Acquisition  whil e ignoring or 
minimizing the abundant evidence of the transaction’s risks. The Commission should consider the entirety of the evidence in the record,  which is thoroughly and fairly presented in the ALJ 
Report, and exercise its own independent judgment based on that evidence.
19 
II. THE ALJ REPORT CORRECTLY APPLIED THE LEGAL STANDARD. 
Petitioners inaccurately claim that the ALJ Report applied an incorrect legal standard in 
this case.20 Sierra Club and other Intervenors have explained that under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, 
the standard for determining whether the Acquisition  is consistent with the public interest 
requires a showing that the transaction would provide affirmative public benefits, not only that it would result in no net harm as Petitioners would have i t.
21 But t he ALJ Report’s legal and factual 
conclusions are sound regardless of which legal standard applies. The ALJ Report included a detailed discussion of the parties’ dispute over the legal standard, including Petitioners’ and Intervenors’ positions and applicable caselaw.
22 The ALJ Report finds that the “net benefit 
standard” likely applies.23 Ultimately, however, the ALJ concludes that “resolution of the correct 
standard is not necessary” because it does not determine the outcome: “[t]he proposed

 transaction does not pass muster under either standard because the Acquisition would result in 
net harm to the public interest. ”24 In other words, even if the ALJ Report had applied Petitioners 
proposed “no net harm” standard rather than a “net benefit” standar d, the Acquisition  would still 
fail to satisfy that standard because the ALJ Report finds that it would result in net harm.  
III. THE EVIDENCE SUPPORTS THE ALJ’ S FINDING THAT THE ACQUISITION 
IS NOT IN THE PUBLIC  INTEREST, WITH OR WITHOUT THE PROPOSED 
SETTLEMENT. 
The evidence in this proceeding shows that the proposed Acquisition  has substantial risks 
and few benefits: it may threaten Minnesota Power’s compliance with the Carbon Free 
Standard,25 does not guarantee access to capital,26 is likely to contribute to higher rates ,27 and 
would result in the Partners’ total control of the ALLETE Board28 and in reduced transparency .29 
Contrary to Petitioners’ claims, the ALJ Report’s factual and legal conclusions on these points are well -supported by the evidentiary record.  
The Proposed Settlement does nothing to change these conclusions , as most of its 
commitments simply describe the status quo or restate existing legal requirements without offering any benefits . The few new commitments in the Proposed Settlement are far too limited 
to be meaningful: they do not mitigate the risks of the Acquisition  and do not provide any 
benefits sufficient to outweigh the Acquisition ’s harms .

 A. The Acquisition  and Proposed Settlement Would Not Ensure a C lean Energy 
Transition or Compliance with the Carbon Free Standard. 
The ALJ Report correctly found that Petitioners have not shown that the proposed 
Acquisition  is necessary or sufficient for the Company to comply with the Carbon Free 
Standard.31 Petitioner s’ attempts to challenge the ALJ Report’s conclusions do not hold water. 
Petitioners claim that the ALJ ignored evidence of the Partners’ supposed commitment to a clean 
energy transition.32 But while Alloy Parent  commits to provide financing for the Company’s 
five-year capital plan, the Partners  have not made an enforceable commitment to provide any 
amount of capital specifically to fund renewable energy .33 And while Petitioners claim that the 
Partners  view complia nce with the Carbon Free Standard as a benefit,34 the Partners have 
declined to commit to achieve the Carbon Free Standard, instead promising only to make “efforts to achieve” the standard , an illusory statement which is not a meaningful commitment.
35 
Moreover, both CPP and Blackrock (owner of GIP) have recently abandoned previous 
organization-wide emissions reduction targets and clean energy  pledges , calling into question 
whether the Partners  remain committed to decarbonization.36 
Petitioners also mischaracterize the ALJ Report, wrongly claiming that the ALJ Report 
called for delaying compliance with the Carbon Free Standard or that the ALJ Report concluded

 that rejecting the Acquisition  would delay compliance with the standard.37 That is not what the 
ALJ Report says. On the contrary, the ALJ Report acknowledged that compliance with the 
Carbon Free Standard is a critically important legal requirement.38 However, the ALJ Report 
found that “[t] he Petitioners did  not prove by a preponderance of evidence that they will be 
unable to meet the Carbon  Free Standard absent the Acquisition , nor did they guarantee or 
present sufficient  evidence showing that the standard will be met as a result of the 
Acquisition .”39 The ALJ Report finds that Petitioners failed to show the Acquisition  is needed to 
meet the Carbon Free Standard or that the standard could not be met if the Company relied on capital from public markets. There is no credible evidence showing that rejecting the Acquisition  
would result in any delay in achieving the Carbon Free Standard.  
Petitioners point to the “Clean Firm Technology Fund” included in the Proposed 
Settlement as a benefit of the Acquisition  and assert that the fund would help facilitate the 
Company’s compliance with the Car bon Free Standard.

 nearly $5 billion in the next five years and $20 billion over the next two decades.41 The proposed 
$50 million commitment is grossly inadequate when the Company’s plans call for billions in 
spending. Moreover, there is no guarantee that the proposed “Clean Firm Techn ology Fund” will 
be used for fully carbon- free technologies.  The Proposed Settlement includes a provision that 
expressly allows Minnesota Power to seek exemptions in order to use the fund for resources that 
do not  meet the Company’s own definition of “clean firm technology” if DOC agrees.42 
Moreover, Minnesota Power and DOC have recently argued in another Commission docket that the statutory definition of “carbon free” should be interpreted to treat carbon -emitting thermal 
generating technologies including solid waste, biomas s, and renewable natural gas as fully or 
partially carbon free.
43 Given the Company’s position on this issue, there is a risk that Minnesota 
Power may seek to use the “Clean Firm Technology Fund” to finance development of carbon-emitting power plants that burn solid waste, biomass, or natural gas. If used in this way, the fund would impede the Company’s progress towards developing a legitimately carbon- free generating 
portfolio rather than helping to achieve the Carbon Free Standard. 
B. Petitioners Have Not Shown That the Acquisition  is Needed or That it Would 
Improve the Company’s Access to Capital . 
The ALJ Report correctly found that Petitioners have failed to demonstrate (1) that the 
Acquisition  is necessary to obtain sufficient capital to comply with the Carbon Free Standard,

 (2) that the Acquisition  is superior to alternative methods of raising capital,  including on public

First, Petitioners have provided no evidence for their claim that compliance with the 
Carbon Free Standard is “highly unlikely ” without the Acquisition .47 Sierra Club does not 
dispute that Min nesota Power needs some amount of capital in order to fund its transition to 
clean energy  or comply with the Caron Free Standard. However, Petitioners have not shown that 
the Company’s true capital need is as large as it claim s. The record shows that the Company has 
consistently over- estimated its capital needs  since 2019.48 Moreover, Intervenor testimony and 
the ALJ Report identified several ways that ALLETE could mitigate its future capital needs ,49 
including via the expanded use of power purchase agreements (“PPAs”) ,50 demand response, 
energy efficiency measures, and grid -enhancing technologies,51 or by selling its stake in joint 
transmission projects  or non- utility subsidiaries.52 Petitioners did not present any concrete 
evidence showing that it would be infeasible to reduce the Company’s capital needs using more 
or more of these strategies.  
Moreover, the ALJ Report correctly found that Petitioners have not shown that ALLETE  
needs the Acquisition  in order to meet its capital needs.53 Petitioners have not demonstrated that

because “[t] here is no guarantee that the Partners will provide capital to Alloy Parent.”59 The 
Partners themselves have not actually committed to provide any capital to ALLETE, as the ALJ Report correctly recognizes.

C. The Acquisition  is Likely to Result in Overspending and Rate Increase s. 
Minnesota Power has expressly acknowledged that it plans to increase rates and provided 
projections of those planned increases, which the Company has fought to keep confidenti al.65

b. ROE is too high , and rates will increase too soon  
 
The ROE and rate case stay -out provisions are exceptionally temporary. As the Department 
admits, “assuming a November 2026 rate case filing, customers would likely benefit from the ROE 
reduction until late 2027 or early 2028.”24 The Department offers no evidence or explanation about 
why northeastern Minnesota’s ratepayers will be so well off in 2028 that they will be able to absorb 
the large rate shock that will undoubtedly occur due to interim and final rate increases because of 
the Partners’ first  rate case. Since the Unites States appears poised to be heading towards a trade -
war-induced recession at the same time that the federal government has significantly cut back on 
safety net  programs, the opposite is much more likely to occur. By 2028, Minnesota’s rural utility 
customers will likely have less disposable income, less affordable healthcare, less access to 
government assistance, less job prospects, and—should this acquisition be approved now —much 
higher utility rates.  
 
Rather than a 0.13 percent adjustment, CURE encourages the Commission to actually address the 
full harm of the high ROE and set Minnesota Power’s at a more reasonable standard: 6 percent.  
This can be done outside of this proceeding in a rate case . A lower ROE  is supported by CURE’s 
testimony in this case, and would go a long way in protecting rural ratepayers from future gold -
plating of Minnesota Power resources in order to inflate unearned profit margins. CURE also 
believes that a one -year rate case stay -out,25  is not sufficient to mitigate the plans  of these private 
equity companies —only a rate case stay -out for the entire time  that Minnesota Power is owned by 
private equity firms (these Partners or any they may sell to in the future) can protect Minnesotans 
from foreseeable harm.

for the gold -plated “carbon free” resources that Minnesota Power likely w ill attempt to pay for 
with this fund.

by this proposed acquisition will hit low -income and marginalized communities the hardest, both 
through rate impacts and by causing economic difficulty for businesses that supply industrial 
employment.33 As the ALJ found : “The Partners’ private memoranda, modeling, and 
communications with potential investors establish that the Partners are planning on significant 
rate increases that will likely exceed the long -run rate of inflation. . . . The Acquisition creates an 
unacceptable risk of rate increase and rate shock in a critical and economically vulnerable area of 
Minnesota.”34 
 
5. Non -party organization  comments  
 
As already discussed, nearly all public comments offered in favor of this acquisition appear to be 
from parties who are financially connected to Minnesota Power or ALLETE. Any additional

10 supportive comments at this point appear to be made in  ignorance of the record before the 
Commission , which clearly demonstrates foreseen harms to workers, the environment, customers 
of all sizes, industrial output and profitability, transparency, accountability, and Minnesota 
Power’s long -term reliability and maintenance .  
 
Members of the public generally do not make technical comments applying legal standards or 
advocating for an outcome on policy grounds, but several organizations filed comments in support 
of this acquisition, purporting to make policy  arguments without  actually having reviewed the 
complete recor d, including the large amount of trade secret materials that generally contradict 
public statements in favor of the acquisition . 
 
These comments are of no substance. They do not reflect the record, they do not reflect the 
Applicants’ past or current business practices, they do not reflect commitments made  nor whether 
these are enforceable by the Commission .  
 
These comments should be given little  weight as they are not based on the facts nor the law 
applicable in this case. They incorrectly assume that the agreement between the Department and 
the Applicants places  financial  duties upon the Partners, while the July 11 stipulation  clearly does 
not require that the Partners provide any funding at all. They incorrectly assume that the 
agreement supports replacing Boswell with “clean energy,”35 which Minnesota Power and the 
other Applicants clearly do not propose  to do —the IRP  expressly plans to replace all of Boswell’s 
generation with fossil gas and/or biomass energy  (an energy so urce more carbon intensive than 
coal) .  
 
These commenters can be forgiven for not knowing anything about this docket, they never 
participated in it before August 4th. None of them sought party status or offered public comment 
during the applicable comment period.  Their disinterest in this docket and the impacted northern 
Minnesota communities —for a full year of proceedings —echoes silently through the record.  
 
These comments also show no concern for negative impacts that have been proven by intervenors 
in testimony and briefing . They ignore the issues of affordability, the Commission’s central duty 
to all Minnesota ratepayers. As such, they are not useful to the Commission as it makes its decision 
on this robust and complex record.  
 
It remains true, as the ALJ clearly found:  
 
At the heart of this matter is the amount of capital Minnesota Power will require,  
and at what times, to comply with Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard. The 
 
35 Fresh Energy  & Clean Grid Alli ance  at 2 (“And certainly, replacing Minnesota Power’s coal with 
clean energy is the basis for its  ability to meet Minnesota’s 100% clean electricity standard and 
economy -wide greenhouse gas  reduction goals.”) . Unfortunately for these commenters, wishing 
doesn’t make it true .  
 
 
 
CUREmn .org    320 -269 -2984  
117 South First Street • Montevideo, MN  56265  
 
11 Petitioners did  not prove by a preponderance of evidence that they will be unable 
to meet the Carbon  Free Standard absent the Acquisition, nor did they guarantee or 
present sufficient  evidence showing that the standard will be met as a result of the 
Acquisition. Furthermore,  the Legislature did not demand utilities, or the 
Commission, pursue the Carbon Free  Standard at all costs. The Commission is 
tasked with ensuring Minnesota Power’s path  to compliance “maximizes net 
benefits to all Minnesota citizens.” U ltimately, even if  declining to approve the 
Acquisition eventually resulted in some complication or short  delay in Minnesota 
Power meeting the Carbon Free Standard, this is not a reason to  approve the 
transaction given its serious risk to Minnesota ratepayers.36 
 
Conclusion  
 
For the foregoing reasons the Commission should deny the petition , and require Minnesota Power 
to commit its past and future land profits to actual renewable energy development and low -
income customer programs.

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The recent “settlement agreement” reached between the Department of Commerce and Minnesota Power and their
private equity backers does very little to address the deep risks this potential deal poses to Minnesota Powercustomers, employees, and the Minnesota public at large. Putting a handful of weak conditions on a fundamentallydangerous bargain does not make it “in the public interest.”
The companies pushing this deal utterly failed to make their case—there is no proof that this funding is needed, nor
that new owners will support the clean energy transition we need. There is no basis upon which to approve this deal,
and a long record of harms and risks supporting denial.
I expect Commissioners to listen to the majority of voices in this proceeding, including the Administrative Law
Judge, who recognize this deal for what it is: a perilous gamble that hands Minnesota’s energy future over torapacious private equity interests at the expense of customers, workers, and local business and industry.
Do your duty under Minnesota law to look out for the best interests of Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans
across the state, and the public as a whole, and reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners. Greater Minnesota communities need consumerprotection and accountable institutions, just like your community.
Sincerely,
Mackenzy Hassett
North Saint Paul, MN 55109-3946mackenzyhassett9505@gmail.com

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
My name is Michael Walker, a retired educator from Minneapolis. I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of
ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners(GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest private equity firm. This acquisition is not consistent withthe public interest.
The recent “settlement agreement” reached between the Department of Commerce and Minnesota Power and their
private equity backers does very little to address the deep risks this potential deal poses to Minnesota Powercustomers, employees, and the Minnesota public at large. Putting a handful of weak conditions on a fundamentallydangerous bargain does not make it “in the public interest.”
The companies pushing this deal utterly failed to make their case—there is no proof that this funding is needed, nor
that new owners will support the clean energy transition we need. There is no basis upon which to approve this deal,and a long record of harms and risks supporting denial.
I expect Commissioners to listen to the majority of voices in this proceeding, including the Administrative Law
Judge, who recognize this deal for what it is: a perilous gamble that hands Minnesota’s energy future over torapacious private equity interests at the expense of customers, workers, and local business and industry.
Do your duty under Minnesota law to look out for the best interests of Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans
across the state, and the public as a whole, and reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners. Greater Minnesota communities need consumerprotection and accountable institutions, just like your community.
Sincerely,
Michael WalkerMinneapolis, MN 55419-5246retmicwalker@gmail.com

To whom it may concern,  
 
 
AEOA’s mission is to strengthen communities by providing opportunities for people 
experiencing social and economic challenges. As part of those efforts, AEOA has worked 
with Minnesota Power on affordability outreach and connecting people to resources to 
assist with energy costs and energy conservation. Specifically, AEOA is a service provider 
for energy assistance and weatherization services in Cook, Lake, and St. Louis 
counties.   This includes the City of Duluth, the largest city in Minnesota Power’s servi ce 
territory.   We have worked closely with Minnesota Power for many years to bring energy 
efficiency measures to customer homes, lower utility bills, and provide energy assistance 
dollars as well as affordability program referrals.  
  
These brief comments are regarding the financial contribution by the Partners described in 
the proposed settlement agreement under 1.48 “to significantly reduce residential arrears 
to pre -COVID -19 balances or lower, an outcome that would benefit all Minnes ota Power 
customers while providing account balance relief to the most economically challenged 
residential customers.”  
  
Given the recent uncertainty about Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program 
(LIHEAP) funding and the considerable need in the areas we serve, many of which include 
Minnesota Power’s customers, we submit this brief letter of support for that part of the 
settlement agreement. We believe additional resources like those described would help to 
bring down balances owed on accounts and give customers some much-needed relief in 
an otherwise rising costs environment. AEOA would be very interested in updates on that 
proposal and would be a willing collaborator on design considerations and outreach.  
 
 
Sincerely,  
 
 
 
Scott Zahorik  
Executive Director

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am a nurse at Minnesota's safety-net hospital. I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota
Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which isowned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest private equity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the publicinterest.
The recent “settlement agreement” reached between the Department of Commerce and Minnesota Power and their
private equity backers does very little to address the deep risks this potential deal poses to Minnesota Powercustomers, employees, and the Minnesota public at large. Putting a handful of weak conditions on a fundamentallydangerous bargain does not make it “in the public interest.”
The companies pushing this deal utterly failed to make their case—there is no proof that this funding is needed, nor
that new owners will support the clean energy transition we need. There is no basis upon which to approve this deal,and a long record of harms and risks supporting denial.

Judge, who recognize this deal for what it is: a perilous gamble that hands Minnesota’s energy future over torapacious private equity interests at the expense of customers, workers, and local business and industry.
Do your duty under Minnesota law to look out for the best interests of Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans
across the state, and the public as a whole, and reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners. Greater Minnesota communities need consumerprotection and accountable institutions, just like your community.
Sincerely,
Elizabeth SongaliaSaint Paul, MN 55107-2721reinsong@q.com
